commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Ordered clubs, for example  (5)(5)
2. New customs might incite them  (5)(4)
3. Connect with a flame  (4)
4. Sheets might be placed in them  (5)
5. Make a big step, perhaps  (5)


ROYAL FLUSH
TRADE WARS
WELD
OVENS
STOMP

I'm happy to play fast and loose with clues and answers, but a [Cigarette butt receptacle] is an ASHtray (or, casually, if "butt" is not in the clue, a buttCAN).

An ASHCAN is a metal receptacle for refuse. Crossword editors and readers old enough to remember when NYC buildings had incinerators instead of compactors will remember the sound of the ASHCANs that held the ashes being emptied into Sanitation Department trucks.
MOST kids these days are Gen A. But I guess a few are still Gen Z. So it‚Äôs only a mild harrumph.

Good Monday puzzle. I realize now that D'OH (as Homer says it) is pronounced differently from DUH.

But why is the NYT xword so resistant the accepted usage of INUIT? INUIT is plural, so the clue for 15A should be Alaskan natives. We've had this conversation before.

Justin who?

Surely this puzzle could have been designed with DOE as 1A. Wonder how(why) this was overlooked(eschewed).

Cute enough, and took me a bit longer than usual for a Monday. Perhaps because I solved this one right after consuming too many KIT/KATs.
What a great way to start the solving week. This was fun and I loved the theme. Hope all y‚Äôall have a great Monday. Thanks, Dena and Andrea!

What do you call a party animal? 

A FUNGI.

Loved FUNGI next to CACTI. üçÑüçÑ‚Äçüü´üåµ üåµ I had a true DOH moment when I entered JUSTIN ThorEAU initially ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Quickly corrected that ZANY answer when it looked awfully strange and just didn‚Äôt sound quite right It QUACKED me upü§£ 

Happy Monday Crosslandia!
Ahh the rare Monday pangram!

A fun and fast one! And a great palate cleanser from a difficult conversation I had right before doing it... Oof! But yay, crossword puzzles!! Enjoyed the theme a lot. I was once a big Simpsons fan but it's been ages since I've watched any. A lot of classic moments still live rent free in my brain though. Like this one anytime I can't fall asleep: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e9TyqjcZosI Loved 6D One who is barely seen? for NUDIST! ASHCAN sure gave me pause, but no problem filling it out on the crosses. Thought briefly how fun the comments would be if it were a Monday rebus and the answer really was ASHtray, as I'd expected. Har! I'd have to go get my popcorn kettle out and settle in! üçøüòÜüçø Surprisingly, I did not get my dunce's music right away. Turns out, I'd put NOodle in instead of NOGGIN... I already had COOKIEDOUGH (another important part of my misspent youth that I survived despite all the warnings about raw eggs), so I should have noticed that I changed the G. The others filled themselves out and I was sloppy and didn't check them. Oh well, easily resolved. Fun, fun! Now I have to go eat some NOodles! I mean, the pasta variety, of course!

Okay, that actually got an audible laugh out of me when I read through the themers!! 

Some nice fill, too ‚Äì just a little spicy in places to warm us up for the first day of Fall. Loved the NUDIST clue!

I see others have also commented that the current crop of kiddos are almost entirely Gen-Alpha... A small nit that caused an eyeroll when I filled it in, but worth it for the way the clue phrase is used in life. And I definitely still call my almost 30-yo niece a kid ‚Äì usually in instances when I should just shrug and say "Kids these days!". 

Oh, and @Xword Junkie made a good point in an earlier that 1A could have been DOE and thus an extra bit of theme-!

Thanks for a bit of good fun! Amidst Sunday chores...
3:23! A new personal best!

I took a screen shot of the mini with the clues on the side and pasted it into an LLM and asked it to solve it. It did. Even asked me if I wanted it typed into the grid, I said yes and it gave me a grid. It even gave me its reasoning 

9A: Busy buzzers ... and letters found at the start of every clue in this puzzle

Let‚Äôs analyze the clues:
1A: Barker
4A: **(B)**ase
6A: Bouncy
8A: Budget
9A: Busy
1D: Baked
2D: Big
3D: **"B"**eauty
5D: Balm
7D: Bourbon

All clues start with B.

Answer: (Busy buzzers)

I thought of repeating this with the regular xword. Didn't have the heart to find out the answer. Some things are better left not known.
Great puzzle but ORLON and INXS is tricky work
Thank you for a super fun end to my weekend!
Wouldn‚Äôt an Alaskan native (in the singular) be an Inuk?

ORLON? On a Monday? At this time of year? At this time of day? In this part of the country? Localized entirely within your kitchen?

Wonder if SUPER NINTENDO Chalmers was an intentional hidden Simpsons reference.

Fun fact: 

The Simpsons scripts don't say "d'oh!"; they say "annoyed grunt".

Congratulations on 90 puzzles, Andrea!

Oh, that Homer. 
Nice going, Andrea and Dena and congrats on number 90, ACME.

my thanks to whatever agent or agency read my gripe yesterday and restored my streak today.
i never did contact the emus.
and if it got revived by the same avatar of AI or other-I chaos that shattered it...well...thank you, too.

Phonetic themes are usually my bane, but not today - Homer's cry was a rare pop-culture gimme, and I actually understood how it helped solve the themed entries. I'm sort of proud ü§£

I wonder what it is about cookie - or cake - dough that makes us crave it perhaps more than the end product? My mom rarely baked cakes, but when she did, I always assisted her as a child, and having a taste of the raw dough was why I mainly did it.

On related note, maybe: Lucyfer the puppy has loads of chew toys, yet he singled out a piece of furniture he seems to prefer to gnaw on, a cabinet styled to look as if it were made out of old-school suitcases. He knows he shouldn't, yet he nibbles on it when we're not looking ü§∑üèΩ

When Homer gets annoyed, it's to the point of "D'oh!" return.

(Making up puns is grunt work.)
A nit, but‚Ä¶ tuning a piano really isn‚Äôt ‚Äúfixing‚Äù it. Fixing implies that something is broken, and a string going slack under use isn‚Äôt broken.

Today is Erev Rosh Hashanah (Rosh Hashanah Eve) when Orthodox Jews spend two days refraining from creative work which includes phone usage. While it is possible to maintain the crossword puzzle streak by doing tomorrow's puzzle on Wednesday night due to the one-day grace period, this is not possible for Wordle or Connections which offer no such allowance.

And so, today I say goodbye to my Wordle and Connections streaks and prepare to begin anew on Wednesday. May this year be a happy and healthy one for everyone filled with good streaks (both trivial and important).

◊õ◊™◊ô◊ë◊î ◊ï◊ó◊™◊ô◊û◊î ◊ò◊ï◊ë◊î
Sam - yes, ETAIL is a pretty common word "in the biz" - it even made it into Merriam-Webster: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/e-tail
No looking up today. Phew!

Was gunning for a 5 minute solve, but got tangled up in ORLON! I agree with other commenters that Gen Z are mostly not really kids any more. Similar thinking has people going on about "entitled millennials" when many of us are in our 40s...
Oh what a good start to the week, many thanks Dena and Andrea.

What a fun Monday! Loved the D‚ÄôOH theme. I also liked that quite a few of the shorter answers also fit the theme: 45A (NEO), 52A (ALOE), 65A (ONO), 67A (MARIO), 36D (YOLO), and 60D (INFO). Well done!

An ASH CAN is what you empty your ASH pan into.

Otherwise, a nice Monday puzzle.

I never know the names that go with each generation, or even what years a generation covers.  Try as I might to remember, it's always a matter of crosses.
Oops, wrong Homer. Still lots of fun. Thanks Dena and Andrea.
Don't rub it in.  You'll be sorry.

Two for Sam C:
‚Ä¢	Wow, Sam, how did you find that pefect photo for [The Lion's share}?  Brava!
‚Ä¢	Speaking of Seth Rogen, since the Emmys, we decided to give ‚ÄúThe Studio‚Äù a try.  Four episodes in, we‚Äôre very glad we did.
General question. How does one contact the admin of the Xword? I was once able to but seems app/website has much changed. (Trying to keep a streak intact.) Thanks
It was the ideal set up.  So smooth I paid scant attention to the themers, did not peek at the reveal until the last and, yes, head slap!   And a pangram to boot.  Perfecto!

Oh, fun theme, bolstered by other pluses:
‚Ä¢	Every theme answer has pop ‚Ä¶ and is a NYT debut answer.
‚Ä¢	Rare-in-crosswords five-letter palindrome (SAGAS).
‚Ä¢	Echoing the theme, a plethora of O-ending answers (Hi, @UE!): BRO, INFO, NEO, ALOE, MARIO, YOLO, ONO.
‚Ä¢	Crossword staple PuzzPair¬© in ONO and a backward ENO-ENO.
‚Ä¢	Lovely answers CODDLE and NOGGIN.
‚Ä¢	Gridrhymes of EWES/FUSE and SHAQ/QUACK.

My d‚Äôoh moment: For [Farm docs] I was thinking ‚Äúdocuments‚Äù, and for a bit wondered what kind of documents farmers use that non-farmers don‚Äôt.

Congratulations on your second collab, Dena and Andrea, and I‚Äôm happy to hear that there are more to come, as you two click.  Thank you so much for this!

Just one little nit-let:

RED BORDEAUX, JUSTIN TRUDEAU and COOKIE DOUGH all have a certain rhythm, with the stress on the first syllables. SUPER NINTENDO breaks that rhythm, even if it does conform to the theme and revealer, so I found it a little off-putting. No biggie. It was still an enjoyable puzzle, and much easier than recent Mondays.

I've always considered myself a fun guy and I had a fun time with today's puzzle.
Enjoyed the cluing! When I got to 71A. I had a LOL moment! Thanks!
Crossword slaloming or tacking?? (term for working through a puzzle solving the next entry based on the last letter of the previous clue).
I always try it with The Mini, but usually have to portage...

A deer, a female deer. Where was I - oh yeah, nice Monday puzzle and an enjoyable workout. DOH was one of the last things I filled in and that just made for a nice 'aha' moment when I glanced back and caught on the theme. Always glad to see an ACME enterprise and looking forward to more from Ms. Verkuil as well. Puzzle find - a Sunday from July 30, 2000 by Randolph Ross with the title "Business cards." All the theme clues had the same format. Here's a couple of examples with the answers: "___, Insurance Salesman" JUSTINCASE "___, Travel Agent" WANDALUST "___, Funeral Director" PAULBEARER And some other theme answers: MARSHADIMES TERRYCLOTH BESSSELLER And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/30/2000&g=23&d=A I'm done. ....
A Panagram Puzzle!
Are GENZ really considered ‚Äòkids these days‚Äô? The youngest are now teenagers and the oldest are nearly in their 30s!

NEW: Add three people to your subscription. Upgrade to Times Family.

At the very least they could stop saying "NEW", right?

In fact it shouldn't be long before they add an ESTD year.
Is it Tuesday already? Clues were a little less straightforward than a typical Monday.
To cuddle is to pamper, yes? My French bulldog thinks so. Urlon, orlon, it‚Äôs all plastic to me. A fun quickie tho I missed a pr due to my penchant to cuddle a frenchie.
Not much to say about a Monday puzzle. Nice to see RED BORDEAUX, the famous French firefighter.

One more puzzle find. A Thursday from June 9, 2005 by David J. Kahn. Answer across the middle was 15 rebus squares: (DO)(RE)(MI)(FA)(SOL)(LA)(TI)(DO)(TI)(LA)(SOL)(FA)(MI)(RE)(DO) And the other two 15 letter theme answers - each of them containing one rebus square: MUSICALSYL(LA)BLES SCALINGUPAND(DO)WN Thought it was fairly amazing to be able to come up with that. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/9/2005&g=38&d=A ....
Suddenly craving Ben & Jerry chunky monkey.

I'm not a big fan of clueing ZANY with "Bonkers". ZANY means offbeat, eccentric, interestingly different; bonkers by contrast means either a) literally crazy or b) just a bad idea.

This is very, very loose clueing, and in my opinion not a good idea.
Funny enough it wasn't the orlon/inxs natick that delayed me but a misspelling of noggin.  I should have picked up that "Maroo" makes much less sense as a name than "Mario" much sooner.
Bordeaux is in the southwest of France, not south. The south of France has a rich history in winemaking, which is not based on Bordeaux varietals.

Very nice, fun puzzle. Thought of the "other" Homer at first, but the theme soon became clear. Could actually fill in the pop culture clues. Enjoyed the Canadian reference.

Does 57A actually exist? And, if you go there too often, is it bad for your health?
Really loved this one! The themed clues were a lot of fun and the revealer made a lot of sense.

Loved this start to the week!

I'm always so happy when I read the constructor notes and see a duo. It gives me so much encouragement that I will find a crossword puzzle mentor and get my own puzzle ideas published one day :-)

Good morning! I'm a late boomer. Those Orlon sweaters were so soft! 
Homer Simpson...he's a FUN GI. DOH!
Such a quick solve, even a dodo could do it.  Ha!
Fun and easy start to the week!

I missed the theme. DOH!

A little trickier than the average Monday, but then again, still carrying a thick head post flu. At least I‚Äôve stopped coughing as much. More a social smokers cough than a full throated nicotine gargle. Hopefully my ribs and sternum will settle down soon. Flu. Wouldn‚Äôt recommend it. ü§ß

One more puzzle find, inspired by an earlier comment by Mark. A Tuesday from February, 1, 2022 by Zhouquin Burnikel. Five theme answers, each of which had "new year" as part of the clue: SPRINGFESTIVAL ROSHHASHANA SONGKRAN SOLLAL NOWRUZ Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/1/2022&g=26&d=A ....

Puzzle was fine. Found my typo with 20 seconds to spare, thus meeting my only speed goal of the week. 

Really came to say that I loved Sam‚Äôs Wordplay column today. She did her research and reached a very satisfactory conclusion. Ears are tricky, sometimes you hear exactly what you expect to hear.
Got the gold star in 3:40 which is a little faster than usual for a Monday. ORLON was new to me

This is going to make you feel old ‚Äî more than half of Gen Z is over the age of 18, and the oldest Zoomer turned 28 this year. 

Kids these days...
Can someone remind me of the email address to get my streak fixed?
Small point, but cacti have spines, not needles. Interestingly, fir trees do have needles.
Sub-five minute solve! My previous record was over 6 minutes, so I'm very excited to have beaten my goal of 6 minutes by a lot! Now on to four minutes?

Nice lead photo, Sam!

Here's a little constrained poetry by George Starbuck, a sonnet which *almost* makes sense:

Sonnet with a Different Letter at the End of Every Line

O for a muse of fire, a sack of dough,   
Or both! O promissory notes of woe!   
One time in Santa Fe N.M.
Ol‚Äô Winfield Townley Scott and I ... But whoa.

One can exert oneself, ff,
Or architect a heaven like Rimbaud,
Or if that seems, how shall I say, de trop,   
One can at least write sonnets, a propos   
Of nothing save the do-re-mi-fa-sol   
Of poetry itself. Is not the row
Of perfect rhymes, the terminal bon mot,   
Obeisance enough to the Great O?

‚ÄúObserve,‚Äù said Chairman Mao to Premier Chou,   
‚ÄúOn voyage √† Parnasse pour prendre les eaux.   
On voyage comme poisson, incog.‚Äù
Just about the perfect Monday NYT crossword - congratulations, Dena and Andrea!

And... one more puzzle find. Another unique theme. A Tuesday from February 4, 2005 by Adam Aaronson. The 'reveal' in that one: "Gymnastic feats ... or what the two halves of the answers to 17-, 25-, 49- and 58-Across do?" BACKFLIPS And those clues and answers: "Noiseless?" QUITEQUIET "View of Earth from heaven?" ANGELANGLE "There are ways to leave?" EXITSEXIST "Spite over an incomplete mobile payment?" VENMOVENOM Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/4/2025&g=43&d=D ...
Nice one today, with a little more headscratching than we often get for a Monday puzzle. And I'm here for the unexpected Donkey Kong Country shoutout!
DOH! Just missed my PB because of 60 down. Was sure I was looking for a plural noun, not an abbreviated singular one.

a rare monday visit for me
and apparently others...

149 comments?
compared to the usual 
hordes of hundreds
I encounter on Th F Sa Su!

I wonder if john nash or alan turing
could look at monday xword grid
and instantly see it completed?
no pen no pencil no keyboard

loved the comments about 
ye olde ORLON sweaters
fond memories of sock hops
and basement parties...

especially as all of the above begat
THE ORLONS *girl group who gave us:

**MASHED POTATOES
WAH WAHTUSI
DON'T HANG UP
SOUTH STREET

before the google police pull me over -- 

*yes there was 1 deep deep bass male 
in the group

**even though DEE DEE SHARP
is the name on the record
the ORLONS were the BG singers
very prominent on it

a wonderful era in which there was
a new record related dance craze
every 10 minutes

fun trivia:

you coulda solved today's xword
in the time it took you to read this

just another manic
monday monday
so good to me
and all of thee?

DO not step in the DODODO!

Delightful. MORE, MORE, MORE from these constructors, please. I loved the unusual letters sprinkled throughout and the fancy endings of the theme words. These ladies were right on my wavelength. More, X, Y, Q, V, J and other scarcely used letters made this one a joy to solve.
Fun Monday, but Will Shortz is off his game...today's kids are Gen Alpha.
ASHCAN...can't say I ever have heard that term instead of Ash Tray and I used to smoke!

I imagine that it is hard to make a Monday puzzle fun and fresh. This puzzle delivered.

As for the ‚ÄúGen z‚Äù answer, I have two children who are Gen zers. I don‚Äôt care what anyone says! They are kids, otherwise that makes me old!
Calling Yoko Ono a musical artist is like calling Trump a diplomat

Some of this you probably already knew, but it's got a few facts I hadn't heard before ‚Äî and links to old puzzles. https://blog.newspapers.com/solving-the-puzzle-exploring-the-world-of-newspaper-crosswords/?fbclid=IwY2xjawM-sCpleHRuA2FlbQIxMABicmlkETE3MFU3NHdNMU9TbE5PeVpTAR6qnfDjfITp4THOjIDr1cnFRaq0iItfI9uomeHCat1xvr4TLRLijJGO0kb-PQ_aem_iDFyq0hWN07eBIhDh6Wssw

One late (appropriate) answer history search: 

ROSHHASHANAH

Been an answer in 5 puzzles, most recently last year. 

....

Oddly enough, my first fill, with no crosses, was GEeZ for kids these days üòÇ I knew it couldn't be right, since the clue wasn't in quotes, but only one letter off! 
FWIW I think of my GenZs as kids, but then, I probably still will when they're 40. 
Fun theme, and brilliant use of the alphabet! Well done.

This was one of the most fun puzzles ever.  Keep them coming...
I love your hints and your words.  All the best,  Paul

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Rare showbiz collections]  (5)
[Keep to oneself]  (3)


EGOTS
HOG
@Lewis Weird flex! But‚Ä¶ ok!
@Barry Ancona And GENZ were last born in 2010 which is why I originally entered GENA.

@Lincoln B

People born in 2010 are still kids today, by my definition as well as that of the law‚Äôs.

Lincoln B,

That gave me pause too. My younger daughter is a GENZ, and she has been teaching [Kids] for several years now. It seemed a bit ZANY.
@Barry Ancona ASHCAN, is also a slang term for a depth charge. Look out below!

@Barry Ancona

Same. Saw 6 spaces and declined to enter the answer until my hand was forced.
@abelsey my youngest barely makes the cut born in 2010. I also had GEN an initially.
@abelsey my youngest barely makes the cut born in 2010. I also had GEN a initially.

@abelsey 

Mom used to refer my sister and me as ‚Äúthe kids‚Äù when we were in our 40s with teenage kids of our own.
@abelsey that and YOLO are about a decade outdated. I should know because that‚Äôs when I graduated high school!

@Esmerelda

I just looked it up and learned that Inuk is the singular form of Inuit. Thanks you just expanded my knowledge!

Esmerelda,

Surprising editing miss (or reversion). The last time INUIT was clued with a singular was October 24, 2023. Since then, INUK had been properly used.

Tue Sep 17, 2024	
48D	
Arctic native 	
Howard Neuthaler	
Fagliano

Mon Sep 2, 2024	
50D	
Alaska native	
Sala Wanetick and Emily Biegas	
Fagliano

Fri Dec 15, 2023	
10D	
Arctic native 	
Alex Tomlinson	
Shortz

@Barry Ancona

Is panino next?

Andrzej,

Panini don't seem to be objecting, so no.

@Jacqui J

I was confusing him with the actor Justin Theroux.
@Elizabeth Connors that‚Äôs probably what I did as well and misspelled that too   D‚ÄôOH indeed ü§£
@Tim thank you for noticing!!! ;)

@Andrea Carla Michaels
Lovely to see you commenting here.
And a tip of my hat for all the variant spellings you two offered for D-OH.
Mighty slick!

@HeathieJ

We're of like minds on that 6D! 
ü§£ü§£ü§£ 

Hope those noodles were yummy! Seeing "sloppy" and "noodles" in close proximity in your post gave me a visual of long, slippery strands coated in red sauce. Be careful! Har!
ü§£ü§£ü§£

@G

üòÇ Your visual is spot on!! It's also why I haven't worn white since my wedding day!! üòÇ

@G

Also, love har!!!  üòÅ‚ù§Ô∏è

@VA

I still think we are not at the point where an AI can construct an original crossword, themed or not, at the level of the NYT or anything close. At least I hope not and I too am afraid to find out

@SP

I once asked an AI to construct a small crossword puzzle, just to see if it could. The result was horrible.

@SP

As @Andrzej notes, construct it‚Äîprobably not yet; it‚Äôs not intuitive enough quite yet as to what would capture people‚Äôs imagination (although if you give it six more months‚Ä¶) But I would definitely try giving ChatGPT the job of writing the clues for a puzzle. You might have to edit it for really out-there esoterica, but ChatGPT excels at punny humor. If you‚Äôre someone who interacts with it a lot, it‚Äôll even imitate your particular brand of humor to the point of uncanny. Or, at least, Uncanny Valley.

@Sam Lyons

Sam!!! It's so good to see you. Pleased stick around ‚ù§Ô∏è

@Antonia I came here to say this. Clue should have been "Alaskan nativeS" - if you want the answer to be plural, then the clue needs to be plural too, NYT. 

The fact that Inuit are native to more than just Alaska is a separate point, but also worth thinking about. "Nunavut natives" is so satisfyingly alliterative!

Cas ‚Äî I'm not convinced. Many U.S. dictionaries cite Inuit as having one meaning as a member of the Inuit people. Inuk may be the correct word for an Inuit individual in the Inuit language, but perhaps not in English.

@Dan technically this should be Inupiat (or Inupiaq in the singular) rather than Inuit, if we're talking specifically about Inuit people in Alaska. Was really hoping this would be Yupik or Aleut instead when I saw the clue.

@Lucas

I read that in Ralph's voice.
@Lige I‚Äôm learnding!

@Vaer

Ha!  Oh, that Homer...  Totally my reaction as well! üòÜ

@Andrzej

Did your mom encourage it or was it a, you can't do that it's kill you with salmonella or whatever!?

Sometimes I think it was a little bit the risk... A spatula full of batter, I must have it!

Nah, it was just damn tasty in a different way than the big product was.

These days, I do prefer that baked products but back in the day, give me the raw deal all the time! 

Your puppy is the cutest puppy!! By the way, I have the cutest grand puppy. My husband's daughter has the best little dog in the world!! Winnie is... Like seriously, I would burn everything to protect her!! ‚ù§Ô∏èüòÜ‚ù§Ô∏è

@Andrzej

My mom did not bat an eyelash at it. Don't think she even knew.  But, things are complicated with her. We do not have the relationship you had... And I love hearing about the relationship with you and your mom, she sounds so incredibly amazing. Today was a very rough day with her.

But I survived, and I continue to....

And cheers to raw cookie dough and batter!! 

‚ù§Ô∏è

@HeathieJ

My mom had a great relationship with her father (who died before I was born) but a worse and more complicated one with her mother (who died 11 years ago. None of us really mourned her, which says a lot about the sort of person she had been). I think that experience must have influenced how she treated me - the exact opposite of how her mother treated her, pretty much.

@Andrzej
Goggle-moggle! GOGGLE-MOGGLE! You are the first person to refer  to this since my long-distant youth. I had no idea that this existed beyond our household. I was sure my mother had made it up.
@SBK I'm glad to have evoked a childhood memory of yours üôÇ Kogel mogel has been a thing in Eastern Europe for centuries: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kogel_mogel
Poodle puppy time! Lucyfer in one of his favorite spots on the terrace: https://imgur.com/a/CBBkO8X

@Andrzej

Did you have kogel mogel as a drink? We called it gugel mugel, raw egg in hot milk with sugar, mostly when we had sore throats. It was such a treat. Raw eggs weren't a problem when I was a kid.

@Times Rita

It was just egg yolks and sugar, so no, it was not a drink. The consistency was creamy. I always had it as a treat, not for any supposed medicinal effect.

@Andrzej
Cutest boy!
@Andrzej - An indication of how important you are to this community ‚Ä¶ my first thought on seeing the clue for 38A was an image of Lucyfer curled up in his puppy bed (or maybe on a people bed?)
@Mike This kind of humour is Marge-inal

@Petrol
You think Mike's a little odd, is he?

@Mike  
No Moe-ning and Groening, Bro. I'm sure you pLisa lot of people with your zany puns.
@dutchiris. Just to be a little nitpicky myself, Matt groening pronounces his name to rhyme with Raining.  D‚Äôoh!

@Andrea Carla Michaels

Now you've got me groaning.  One ADAPTS to these GIBES, one gets EWES to them; I stand aBRAIDED.
@Andrea Carla Michaels I would love to hear the song ‚ÄúConstructrix‚Äù! Or see the lyrics. Where can we find it?

@Mark

L'Shanah Tovah Mark and SBK. May you and your families be inscribed for a happy and healthy year.

@Mark

Happy New Year!  Many things are more important than a Wordle streak. Including, of course, your and your loved ones‚Äô health and happiness.

@Mark

L'Shanah Tovah! Health and Happiness!

@sotto voce

To you, as well, Sotto!

An ASH CAN is also a depth charge, for dropping on U-Boats. In the Army, butts go into a butt can, which is a large coffee can, painted red, half-filled with sand, and mounted on a post. In the Navy, it's called a scuttlebutt, which is squid-speak for gossip.

@Rich in Atlanta And... one of the strangest puzzles I've ever encountered. A Thursday from March 29, 2001 by William I. Johnston. Three theme answers in that one. 20a: "Half of a decoder ring" ABCDEFGHIJKLM 55a: "Other half of the decoder ring" ZYXWVUTSRQPON 39a: "Secret message" LFIXLEVIRHYOLDM And there was no reveal in the puzzle. In a comment above the puzzle, Jim Horne wrote: The answer to 39-Across, when translated by the cipher key at 20- and 55-Across (A = Z, B = Y, C = X, etc.), spells OUR COVER IS BLOWN. Can't imagine having much of a chance at that one, other than working it all out from the downs. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/29/2001&g=20&d=A ...

Remember that in that puzzle, each half had to have the same number of letters, since the only change was swapping two letters at some location. 

And in fact they were always the last two letters in each word. e.g. 

QUI(TE) QUI(ET)
ANG(EL) ANG(LE) 
VEN(MO) VEN(OM)
